clinical_study.brief_title: Division-less Gastric Bypass, Step to Decrease Cost and Early Nightmare of Bariateric Surgery
clinical_study.official_title: Division-less Gastric Bypass, True Mini Gastric Bypass, Step to Decrease Cost and Early Nightmare of Bariateric Surgery

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to determine the efficacy of of gastric bypass without gastric division as a treatment for morbid obesity

detailed_description.textblock: in this study the investigators aim to test a new technique for gastric bypass as a treatment for morbid obesity which is division-less gastric bypass in comparison to mini-gastric bypass. in this study 50 patients with morbid obesity will included in the study , randomly will divided into 2 group each, group will include 25 patients. group 1 will operated with division-less gastric bypass, while group 2 will operated by min-gastric by pass.

primary_outcome.description: the total cost for the operation
the operative time from skin incision to skin closure
intraoperative complications like bleeding, other organs injuries

secondary_outcome.description: the percentage of weight loss from total excess body weight

secondary_outcome.measure: effect on metabolic syndrome if present
secondary_outcome.description: effect on blood sugar level, blood pressure and blood cholesterol level

other_outcome.description: the presence of postoperative biliary reflux clinically and by upper endoscopy

intervention.description: in division-less gastric bypass, the investigators will do the gastric bypass without division of the stomach into 2 part (pouch part and the rest of the stomach that still connected to the duodenum) but the pouch which will anatomised with the small intestine is excluded from within, in comparison to standard mini-gastric bypass so that we try to decrease the cost of stapler and its complication
classic laparoscopic mini-gastric bypass as described by Rutledge

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- obese patients with BMI more than 50
- patients fit for laparoscopic surgery
- give approval to share in the study
Exclusion Criteria:
- patients refused to share in the study
- patients unfit for surgery
- patients aged less than 18 and older than 50
- patients with BMI less than 50
- patient with previous upper abdominal surgery either for obesity or other diseases
- patients with preoperative GERD clinically or by investigation
